title: Uber, Google targeted by new global tax
text:
"Where you have huge investments, marketing investments in the markets, where you have a special relationship in the market, you would be in scope."

Companies such as Google and Uber and other businesses with sustained engagement in a market would be captured under the changes irrespective of whether there was any physical presence, he added.

"That covers the [business-to-consumer], that extends to part of the [business-to-business]." The OECD did not outline what the threshold should be.

'A new top-down approach'

The changes would also introduce a new taxing right against any of the businesses that were captured under the sales threshold test.

The level of tax would redistribute the global earnings of a company where they exceed a pre-determined level.

If Company X has a global profitability margin of 35 per cent and the margin deemed to be "routine" was 10 per cent, Mr Saint-Amans explained, then the 25 per cent of "residual profits" would be redistributed between the jurisdictions in which they were generated.

"This is a new top-down approach ... which doesn't build on existing transfer pricing rules, it is added to it," he said.

The proposed changes will be open for input until early next month, before being considered by Australia and other jurisdictions.

"A multilateral, consensus-based solution to the tax challenges arising from digitalisation is key to ensuring the integrity of our tax system," Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said.

"We will consider any proposals with a view to ensuring that all companies pay their fair share of tax in Australia."

The OECD wants to establish international agreement on the required reforms by next year.

'They will likely fight this'

Former ATO executive Tania Waterhouse said digital giants were likely to strongly resist any new agreement.

The Waterhouse Lawyers principal director said Australia was well placed on tax minimisation laws but considered the 2020 deadline "optimistic".

"I think it's unfortunate that Australia withdrew one of our planned measures," she said.

The federal government had considered a unilateral plan for standalone rules to tax online advertising and intermediation services. Amid warnings of retaliation from the Trump administration, the plan was dropped.

"France has gone on its own already, so why should we be waiting here?" Ms Waterhouse said.

"I think big companies will take this new development very, very seriously. Amazon, Facebook and Google are all US-based entities.

"They will likely fight this."
description: Tech giants like Google and Uber would be forced to pay increased tax based under proposed global tax changes that would have ramifications around the world.
